TouchEvent.summary: The TouchEvent interface represents an which is sent when the state of contacts with a touch-sensitive surface changes. This surface can be a touch screen or trackpad, for example. The event can describe one or more points of contact with the screen and includes support for detecting movement, addition and removal of contact points, and so forth.

remarks.para: Touches are represented by the object; each touch is described by a position, size and shape, amount of pressure, and target element. Lists of touches are represented by objects.

TouchEventTargetTouches.summary: The targetTouches read-only property is a listing all the objects for touch points that are still in contact with the touch surface and whose event occurred inside the same target as the current target element.
TouchEventTargetTouches.value: A listing all the objects for touch points that are still in contact with the touch surface and whose touchstart event occurred inside the same target as the current target element.

TouchEventChangedTouches.summary: The changedTouches read-only property is a whose touch points ( objects) varies depending on the event type, as follows:
TouchEventChangedTouches.value: A whose objects include all the touch points that contributed to this touch event.

TouchEventMetaKey.summary: The read-only metaKey property of the interface returns a boolean value indicating whether or not the <kbd>Meta</kbd> key is enabled when the touch event is created. If this key is enabled, the attribute's value is true. Otherwise, it is false.

blockquote.para: On Macintosh keyboards, this is the <kbd>⌘ Command</kbd> key. On Windows keyboards, this is the Windows key (<kbd>⊞</kbd>).

TouchEventMetaKey.value: A boolean value that is true if the <kbd>Meta</kbd> key is enabled for this event; and false if the <kbd>Meta</kbd> is not enabled.

TouchEventShiftKey.summary: The read-only shiftKey property of the TouchEvent interface returns a boolean value indicating whether or not the <kbd>shift</kbd> key is enabled when the touch event is created. If this key is enabled, the attribute's value is true. Otherwise, it is false.
TouchEventShiftKey.value: The boolean value true if the <kbd>shift</kbd> key is enabled for this event; and false if the <kbd>shift</kbd> key is not enabled.

TouchEventCtrlKey.summary: The read-only ctrlKey property of the interface returns a boolean value indicating whether the <kbd>control</kbd> (Control) key is enabled when the touch event is created. If this key is enabled, the attribute's value is true. Otherwise, it is false.
TouchEventCtrlKey.value: A boolean value that is true if the <kbd>control</kbd> key is enabled for this event; and false if the <kbd>control</kbd> is not enabled.

TouchEventTouchEvent.summary: The TouchEvent() constructor creates a new object.

blockquote.para:
If you construct a synthetic event using this constructor, that event will not be trusted, for security reasons.
Only browser-generated TouchEvent objects are trusted and only trusted events trigger default actions.

remarks.para: -, the interface of the objects it constructs.

TouchEventTouches.summary:
touches is a read-only listing
all the objects for touch points that are currently in contact
with the touch surface, regardless of whether or not they've changed or what their
target element was at time.

remarks.para:
You can think of it as how many separate fingers are able to be identified as touching
the screen.

blockquote.para:
Touches inside the array are not necessarily ordered by order of occurrences (the
i-th element in the array being the i-th touch that happened). You cannot assume a specific order. To determine the order of occurrences of the touches, use the touch object IDs.

TouchEventTouches.value:
A listing all the objects for touch points that are still in contact with the touch surface, regardless of whether or not they've changed or what their target element was at touchstart
time.

TouchEventAltKey.summary: The read-only altKey property of the interface returns a boolean value indicating whether or not the <kbd>alt</kbd> (Alternate) key is enabled when the touch event is created. If the <kbd>alt</kbd> key is enabled, the attribute's value is true. Otherwise, it is false.
TouchEventAltKey.value: A boolean value that is true if the <kbd>alt</kbd> key is enabled for this event; and false if the <kbd>alt</kbd> is not enabled.
